title: My Year Portfolio — Selecting Best Work
description: The child reviews all their work from the year and selects pieces that represent their best effort and growth. This capstone project teaches self-reflection, organization, and pride in accomplishment.
instructions:
1. Gather all saved work from the year: art projects, writing samples, math work, nature journals, etc.
2. Spread work across a large surface (floor or table) and sort by season or quarter.
3. 'Look at everything you have done this year! Let's choose your very best pieces.'
4. Guide the child to select 2-3 items from each quarter that they feel proud of.
5. For each piece, ask: 'Why did you choose this one? What do you remember about making it?'
6. Begin organizing selected pieces chronologically.
7. Clean up remaining work — return to storage or recycle as appropriate.
materials_needed: All saved work from the year
Large floor mat or table space

slides.heading: My Year Portfolio
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at this! It says "My Year Portfolio" and "Choosing My Best Work." That means we get to look at all the super cool things you made this whole school year and pick your very favorites!

items: All saved work from the year
slides.setup_instructions: Before the lesson, gather all saved work from cubbies, folders, and shelves. Clear a large floor or table space.
slides.mascot_explanation: Oh, look at all these things we need! We need all your special papers and drawings you saved. We also need a big space, like the floor or a big table, to spread everything out. And we need little sticky notes and a special folder for our favorite things. Ask your grown-up to help you find all these things!

slides.text: 'Look at all the work you have done this year! From your very first day until now. Let's spread it all out and look together.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's look at all the amazing things you've done this year! See all your drawings and papers? We're going to spread them all out so we can see everything from when you first started school until right now.

slides.text: 'Let's sort it by when you did it — fall, winter, and spring. Can you remember when you made each one?'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's put your work in order, like a story! We'll put the fall things here, the winter things here, and the spring things here. Can you remember which season you made each picture or paper?

slides.text: 'Now choose your favorites — the ones you worked hardest on or feel most proud of. Pick 2 or 3 from each time of year.'
slides.mascot_explanation: This is the fun part! Let's pick out your very best work from each season. Choose 2 or 3 things that you worked really hard on, or that make you feel super happy and proud!

slides.text: 'For each one you choose, let's write a little note about it. What do you remember? Why is this one special?'
slides.mascot_explanation: For each special paper you picked, we're going to write a little note on a sticky note. We'll write down what you remember about making it, or why it's so special to you.

slides.prompt: Select your favorite work from the whole year. Write a sticky note for each one telling why you chose it. Put them in order from first to last.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's time to put your favorite things together! Take your chosen papers and put a little sticky note on each one telling why you love it. Then, let's put them in order from the very first thing you made to the last thing.

slides.text: Place your chosen work carefully in the portfolio binder. This is YOUR book of the year — a record of everything you learned and accomplished!
slides.mastery_check: Can the child articulate why they chose specific pieces and describe what they learned from the work?
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay! We did it! Look at your special portfolio, all filled with your amazing work. This is like your own special book that shows how much you learned and how awesome you are!

parent_notes: This portfolio project is deeply Montessori — it honors the child's work and gives them ownership of their learning journey. Resist the urge to choose FOR the child. Their selections reveal what matters to them, which may surprise you. A child might choose a simple pouring exercise over an elaborate art project because the pouring represented a personal breakthrough. Ask open-ended questions: 'Tell me about this one.' Document their verbal reflections on the sticky notes if they cannot write them yet. This portfolio becomes a treasured keepsake and a powerful tool for seeing growth over time.

title: My Book — Planning and Brainstorming
description: The child begins their capstone writing project: creating a personal book. Today they choose their topic — either 'My Kindergarten Year' memoir or an original story — and plan the pages.
instructions:
1. 'This week, you are going to write and illustrate your very own BOOK!'
2. Show examples of both options: a memoir about their year, or an original story.
3. Discuss: 'Which would you like to make? A book about YOUR year, or a make-believe story?'
4. Once the child chooses, brainstorm together. For memoir: list favorite memories from each season. For fiction: who, where, what happens?
5. Create a simple story map or page plan (6-8 pages).
6. Number blank pages and write one sentence plan for each page.
7. 'Tomorrow we start writing!'

slides.heading: My Very Own Book
slides.mascot_explanation: Look, this is so exciting! We get to make our very own book, and today we're going to be the authors and plan it all out. Isn't that super cool?

slides.setup_instructions: Prepare blank booklets by folding and stapling paper. Have planning paper ready with numbered boxes for each page.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at all these fun things we need for our special book! We have a blank book for us to fill, paper to plan our story, and a pencil and crayons to draw. There are also some example books here to give us ideas, so let's look at those!

slides.text: 'This week you are going to be an AUTHOR! You will write and draw your very own book that people can read!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Guess what? This week, you get to be a super-duper author! That means you get to write and draw your very own book that everyone will love to read. How amazing is that?

slides.text: 'You can write about your real year — all the things you learned and did. Or you can write a make-believe story. Which sounds exciting to you?'
slides.mascot_explanation: We have two super fun choices for our book. We can write about all the amazing things you did this year in kindergarten, or we can make up a totally new, pretend story! Which one makes you feel like dancing with excitement?

slides.text: 'Every good book starts with a PLAN. Let's think about what will go on each page. Page 1 is the cover — what will your title be?'
slides.mascot_explanation: Every great book needs a plan, just like building with blocks! We're going to think about what goes on each page, starting with the cover – what do you think we should name your awesome book?

slides.text: 'Now let's plan the middle pages. What happens first? Next? Last? Write one idea for each page.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we get to plan what happens in the middle of our story! We'll think about what happens first, then what happens next, and finally how it all ends. We'll write down one little idea for each page to help us remember.

slides.prompt: Fill in your page plan — write or draw one idea for each page of your book. Think about a beginning, middle, and end!
slides.mascot_explanation: It's time to make our plan for the book! We'll think about the beginning, the middle, and the end, and draw or write one idea for each page. You can do this, and it will help us make a super story!

slides.text: 'You have a wonderful plan! Tomorrow we will start writing the words and drawing the pictures. Your book is going to be amazing!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child articulate their book topic and describe what will happen on at least 4 pages?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did it! You have a wonderful, amazing plan for your book! Tomorrow we'll start filling it with words and drawings, and your book is going to be the best ever.

parent_notes: This capstone writing project synthesizes everything the child has learned about language this year: letter formation, phonetic spelling, sentence structure, storytelling, and illustration. Let the child choose their topic freely — ownership is essential for motivation. For the memoir option, pull out the calendar or photo album to jog memories. For fiction, help them structure a simple plot but let the ideas be theirs. Inventive spelling is perfectly fine — the goal is confident, joyful expression. This book will be presented to family at the end of the week, so build excitement!

title: Math Portfolio — Number Rods and Spindle Box Demonstration
description: The child begins their math capstone by revisiting the earliest math materials. They demonstrate mastery of number rods (1-10) and spindle box, explaining each to the parent as if teaching a younger child.
instructions:
1. 'This week, we are making a Math Museum! You will show everything you have learned in math this year.'
2. 'Let's start at the very beginning. Do you remember the number rods?'
3. Child retrieves number rods and builds the staircase independently.
4. 'Now pretend I am a little child who has never seen these. Teach me!'
5. Child demonstrates and explains the rods: counting, comparing, combining.
6. Move to spindle box: child demonstrates placing correct spindles, explaining zero.
7. Take a photo or sketch the demonstrations for the portfolio.
materials_needed: Portfolio notebook or camera for documentation

slides.heading: Math Museum
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at this! We're going to make a special Math Museum to show everyone how smart you are with numbers. We'll start with some of your very first math tools!

slides.setup_instructions: Place number rods and spindle box on the shelf. The child will retrieve and set up each one independently.
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's get our math treasures ready for our museum! We need the long, colorful number rods and the special box with little holes called the spindle box. We also need our soft floor mat to work on, and then we'll take a picture to show how great you are!

slides.text: 'This week we are building a MATH MUSEUM! You will show all the math materials you have learned to use. Let's start with the very first ones!'
slides.mascot_explanation: This week is super exciting because we're building a MATH MUSEUM! It's like a special place to show off all the amazing math things you've learned this year. We're going to start with the very first math things you ever played with!

slides.text: 'Get the number rods from the shelf. Build the staircase — you know exactly how!'
slides.mascot_explanation: It's time to get our number rods! Remember how they all fit together? Go find them and build that beautiful staircase, just like you always do so well!

slides.text: 'Now teach ME! Pretend I have never seen these rods before. What are they? How do they work?'
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, now you get to be the teacher! Imagine I'm a little friend who has never seen these rods before. Can you show me what they are and how they help us learn about counting?

slides.text: 'Beautiful! Now let's look at the spindle box. Show me how it works. What is special about the zero compartment?'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now let's look at the spindle box! Can you show me how to put the little sticks into the holes? And what's extra special about that one empty hole? Tell me all about it!

slides.prompt: Build the number rod staircase and demonstrate the spindle box. Explain each one as if you are the teacher! We will take a photo for your Math Museum.
slides.mascot_explanation: This is the big moment for our museum! You're going to build the number rod staircase and show me how the spindle box works, explaining it all like a super teacher. Then we'll take a picture to put in your amazing Math Museum!

slides.text: 'You explained that so clearly! You really understand numbers. Tomorrow we will add more materials to our Math Museum.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child independently set up and explain both materials, including the concept of zero?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did such a wonderful job teaching me about the number rods and the spindle box! You really know your numbers, and you explained everything so clearly. We'll add more cool math things to your museum tomorrow!

parent_notes: The Math Museum concept transforms review into something exciting — the child becomes the teacher. This reversal is deeply Montessori: teaching solidifies understanding and builds confidence. You may be amazed at how fluently your child explains concepts they learned months ago. If they struggle with an early material, that is valuable diagnostic information, but this week keep the tone celebratory. Document their demonstrations with photos or video — these are priceless records of growth. The progression from concrete (rods) through semi-abstract (spindles with zero) shows the beautiful Montessori math sequence.

title: My World Map — Places I Have Explored
description: The child creates a personal world map marking all the continents and countries they studied throughout the year. This capstone geography project synthesizes their global knowledge into one beautiful display.
instructions:
1. Provide a large outline world map (or let the child trace one from the puzzle map).
2. 'This year we traveled the world together! Let's mark all the places we learned about.'
3. Review each continent studied: 'What countries did we learn about in Africa? Asia? Europe?'
4. Child colors each continent its Montessori color and labels countries studied.
5. Add small drawings or symbols for memorable facts: pyramids in Egypt, kangaroos in Australia, etc.
6. Add a title: 'My World — Places I Explored This Year.'
7. Display proudly or add to portfolio.
materials_needed: Colored pencils in Montessori continent colors

slides.heading: My World Map
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at this big title! It says "My World Map" and "Places I Explored This Year." This is like the cover of your special book that shows all the amazing places we learned about together.

items: Globe or puzzle maps for reference
slides.setup_instructions: Print or trace a large outline world map. Gather continent-colored pencils: orange (North America), pink (South America), green (Africa), red (Europe), yellow (Asia), brown (Australia), white (Antarctica).
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at all these cool things we need to make our map! We have a big map with no colors, special colored pencils for each part of the world, and a pencil for writing. We'll also use our globe or puzzle maps to help us remember where things are. Ask your grown-up to help you find all these treasures!

slides.text: 'We have traveled the whole world this year with our maps and studies! Let's make YOUR world map showing everywhere we went.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Our big adventure starts now! We've been on so many journeys learning about different countries. Now, we get to make our very own map to show everyone all the wonderful places we discovered this year.

slides.text: 'Start by coloring each continent its special color. Do you remember? North America is orange, South America is pink...'
slides.mascot_explanation: It's time to add some color to our world! Remember how each big piece of land, called a continent, has its own special color? Let's color North America orange, South America pink, and all the others too.

slides.text: 'Now let's mark the countries we studied. Can you remember which ones? I will help you find them on the map.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we get to remember all the cool countries inside those big continents! Let's think hard and find the countries we learned about, like Egypt or China, and put them on our map. I'm here to help you find them!

slides.text: 'Add little drawings for things you remember! Pyramids in Egypt, the Great Wall in China, penguins in Antarctica...'
slides.mascot_explanation: This is the super fun part! Let's draw little pictures of things we remember from each place. Maybe you want to draw a pyramid where we learned about Egypt, or a bouncy kangaroo for Australia!

slides.prompt: Color all seven continents and mark at least one country or landmark you learned about on each one. Add your favorite drawings and details!
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's time to put all our learning together! Let's color all the continents their special colors and draw at least one thing we remember in each one. You can add drawings of the pyramids, or kangaroos, or anything you like! You're doing such a great job!

slides.text: 'What an incredible map! You have learned about the whole world this year. Every continent, so many countries and cultures!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child name and locate all seven continents and recall at least one fact about a country on each?
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at your amazing map! You have filled it with so many colors and drawings. You learned about all seven continents and so many countries this year – you are a world explorer!

parent_notes: This map becomes a beautiful visual record of the child's geographic journey. Use the Montessori continent colors consistently (these vary slightly by tradition — use whatever your materials use). Don't worry if the child's recall is imperfect — prompt gently with 'Remember when we learned about...' and let memories surface naturally. This activity also reinforces fine motor skills (coloring within borders) and spatial awareness. Consider laminating the finished map or framing it. The child's personal connection to world geography — 'I know about Kenya!' — is the foundation for deeper cultural understanding in elementary.

title: Read-Aloud: Not a Box by Antoinette Portis
description: Reading 'Not a Box' by Antoinette Portis, a clever story about a rabbit who insists that the box is not just a box — it's a race car, a mountain, a robot, and whatever imagination makes it.
instructions:
1. Show the cover. 'It's a box... or IS it?'
2. Read aloud — the simple text and brilliant illustrations play off each other.
3. Each time the narrator says 'a box,' let the child guess what the rabbit sees.
4. The red-line illustrations show what the box becomes in the rabbit's imagination.
5. Discuss: 'What would YOUR box be? What can you imagine?'
6. If you have a box, play with it! It's NOT a box!
materials_needed: Not a Box by Antoinette Portis
Optional: a cardboard box for imaginative play

slides.heading: Read-Aloud
slides.subheading: Not a Box by Antoinette Portis
slides.mascot_explanation: Look, we're going to read a super fun book called "Not a Box"! It's all about a little rabbit and a special box. Let's get ready to read!

slides.setup_instructions: Have the book and ideally a box ready for play after reading.
slides.mascot_explanation: To have the most fun, we need our book, "Not a Box." If you have a box around, like one from toys or groceries, that would be extra fun to play with later! Ask a grown-up to help you find them.

slides.text: Cover: 'Someone thinks this is just a box. But the rabbit says it's NOT a box! What could it be?'
slides.mascot_explanation: See the picture on the cover? It looks like a box, right? But the rabbit in our story says it's NOT a box! What do YOU think it could be instead?

slides.text: Read with playful exasperation. 'It's NOT a box!' Let the child guess before turning each page.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we're going to read the story! When the rabbit says "It's not a box!", we'll stop and you can tell me what you think it really is. It's like a guessing game!

slides.text: Discuss: 'What did the box become? A race car? A mountain? How does imagination work?'
slides.mascot_explanation: The bunny in the book uses his imagination to pretend the box is all sorts of amazing things! What did you see the box turn into? Maybe a speedy car or a giant mountain?

slides.prompt: Find a box (any size!) and play! What is it? A boat? A castle? A spaceship? It's NOT a box!
slides.mascot_explanation: It's playtime! If you have a box, let's pretend it's not a box at all! Can you make it into a pirate ship or a cozy house? We can imagine anything we want!

slides.text: 'A box is never just a box when you use your imagination. What will you imagine next?'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child transform a box (or any object) into at least two imaginary things?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, you were so good at imagining! You showed that a box can be anything you dream up, not just a box. What amazing thing will you pretend next time?

parent_notes: This deceptively simple book celebrates the power of imagination — a core value in Montessori education. It shows that open-ended materials (like a box) inspire richer play than predetermined toys. The minimal text makes it perfect for emerging readers. Consider keeping a 'beautiful junk' collection of boxes and materials for creative play.

title: Sensorial Capstone — Mystery Bag Challenge
description: The child demonstrates mastery of stereognostic sense by identifying geometric solids, everyday objects, and natural materials by touch alone. This capstone activity celebrates their refined sensory discrimination.
instructions:
1. Prepare a mystery bag with 10-12 items: geometric solids, fabric swatches, natural objects (pinecone, shell, stone), small tools.
2. 'Your hands have learned to SEE without your eyes this year! Let's test your amazing sense of touch.'
3. Child closes eyes or uses blindfold. Place one item in their hands.
4. Child feels carefully, names the object, and describes its properties (smooth, rough, heavy, pointed).
5. After identifying, child opens eyes to verify.
6. Continue through all items, celebrating each correct identification.
7. Count successes: 'You identified __ out of __ just by touch!'
materials_needed: Geometric solids (sphere, cube, cylinder, cone, pyramid)

slides.heading: Sensorial Capstone
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at this! It says "Mystery Bag Master Challenge" – that sounds like so much fun! We're going to play a game where we use our super-duper sense of touch.

slides.setup_instructions: Place 10-12 diverse items in the bag. Include items of varying texture, weight, shape, and temperature.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, friend, let's get our special things ready for our game! We need a bag to hide our treasures in, or maybe just a soft cloth to cover our eyes. Then, we'll find some cool shapes like blocks, soft bits of fuzzy stuff, and maybe even a smooth stone or a bumpy pinecone.

slides.text: 'All year your hands have been learning to feel and know things without looking. Today we find out just how amazing your sense of touch has become!'
slides.mascot_explanation: This is so exciting! All year long, your hands have been learning so much, like how to feel different things without even looking. Today is like a special test to see how smart your hands have gotten!

slides.text: 'Close your eyes. I will put something in your hands. Feel it carefully — is it smooth or rough? Heavy or light? What shape is it?'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's play a little game! Close your eyes really tight, or let's cover them with our soft cloth. I'm going to give you something to hold, and I want you to feel it all over with your hands. Is it bumpy or smooth? Is it big and heavy or small and light?

slides.text: Place the first item. Wait patiently. If the child needs help: 'Does it have edges? Is it round? What does it remind you of?'
slides.mascot_explanation: Take your time feeling this special thing. Does it have any pointy parts, or is it all round and soft? Think about what it feels like. Does it remind you of anything you know?

slides.text: 'Open your eyes! Were you right? Let's try another one!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay, you did it! Now you can open your eyes and see if you were right about what you felt. That was amazing! Let's try it again with something new.

slides.prompt: Feel each item in the mystery bag with your eyes closed. Name it, then describe what it feels like — smooth, rough, warm, cold, heavy, light. How many can you get right?
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to be the mystery master! Close your eyes and feel each thing in the bag. Tell me what it is and what it feels like – is it rough like sandpaper or soft like a bunny? Let's see how many you can guess correctly!

slides.text: 'Your sense of touch is incredible! You could feel the difference between silk and burlap, a sphere and a cube. Your hands are very wise!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child correctly identify at least 8 of 12 items by touch and describe their sensory properties?
slides.mascot_explanation: You are a mystery bag superstar! Your hands are so smart, they knew all those things even with your eyes closed! You could tell the difference between fuzzy fabric and a hard block – that's amazing!

parent_notes: The stereognostic sense — knowing through touch — is one of Montessori's unique contributions. This capstone activity demonstrates how much the child's tactile discrimination has developed. At the beginning of the year, they might have identified 2-3 items by touch; now they should recognize many more and use precise vocabulary (smooth, rough, angular, cylindrical). Celebrate every correct answer enthusiastically. If they miss some, that is fine — the goal is to show growth, not perfection. This refined sensory awareness transfers to everything: handwriting (feeling letter shapes), math (manipulating materials with precision), and science (observing closely).

title: My Book — Writing the First Draft
description: The child writes the text for their personal book using their page plan from yesterday. They focus on getting their ideas on paper using all the writing skills they have developed this year.
instructions:
1. Review the page plan from yesterday: 'You have a wonderful plan. Today we write the words!'
2. Start with the cover page: title and author name.
3. Work through each page. Child writes sentences using their plan.
4. Encourage phonetic spelling: 'Write the sounds you hear. You can do this!'
5. Offer spelling help only when asked.
6. Read each page aloud after writing to check it makes sense.
7. 'Tomorrow we will add the illustrations!'

slides.heading: My Very Own Book
slides.mascot_explanation: Look! We get to make our very own book today! It's called "Writing Day," and we're going to fill it with all your amazing ideas.

slides.setup_instructions: Have the page plan visible. Open to the first page of the booklet.
slides.mascot_explanation: We need a few special things to make our book. We have a blank book for our words, your special plan from yesterday, a pencil to write with, and an eraser just in case we need to fix a little oopsie. Let's get them ready!

slides.text: 'Let's look at your plan. Yesterday you decided what goes on each page. Today we write the WORDS! Let's start with the cover.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Remember your super plan from yesterday? We're going to use it today to write all the words for our book! First, we'll make the cover special by writing the title and your name, because YOU are the author!

slides.text: 'Write your title nice and big on the cover. And underneath: By [child's name]. You are an author!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's time for the cover! Let's write the title of your book nice and big right here. And then, underneath, we'll write "By" and then your name, because you are the author of this wonderful story!

slides.text: 'Now page one. Look at your plan — what did you want to say? Write it down! Sound out any tricky words.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, let's turn to the first page. What did your plan say you wanted to write here? Let's try our best to write those words down, and if a word is tricky, let's listen for the sounds to help us spell it!

slides.text: 'Read it back to me. Does it sound right? Does it say what you want it to say? Let's keep going!'
slides.mascot_explanation: After you write your words, let's read them out loud together. Does it sound like what you wanted to say? We're doing such a great job writing our story!

slides.prompt: Write the words for each page of your book. Use your plan to remember what goes on each page. Sound out words you are not sure about!
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's time for you to be the writer! Look at your plan for each page and write down all your wonderful words. Listen for the sounds in the words, and don't worry if it's not perfect spelling – we're just getting our ideas down!

slides.text: 'You wrote a whole book! Every page has words that YOU wrote. Tomorrow we will make it even more beautiful with illustrations!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child write at least one sentence per page using phonetic spelling and/or conventional spelling?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, you did it! You wrote a whole book with your own words on every page! You are such a fantastic writer, and tomorrow we'll get to add beautiful pictures to make it even more special.

parent_notes: This is where you see the full arc of the child's literacy development. Compare their writing now to early-year attempts — the growth will be remarkable. Accept inventive spelling warmly; phonetic spelling IS correct spelling at this stage. If the child writes 'butterfli' for butterfly, they have demonstrated mastery of blends, digraphs, and long vowel patterns! Only correct spelling if the child specifically asks 'Is this right?' Keep the energy positive and productive. Some children will write one sentence per page; others may write paragraphs. Both are wonderful. The goal is confident, independent authorship.

title: Math Portfolio — Golden Beads and Stamp Game Demonstration
description: Continuing the Math Museum, the child demonstrates mastery of golden bead operations and the stamp game. They show how to build numbers, add, subtract, and explain the connection between concrete and abstract.
instructions:
1. 'Today we add more to our Math Museum! Let's show the golden beads and stamp game.'
2. Child builds a 4-digit number with golden beads (e.g., 2,345).
3. 'Teach me! What does each bead represent?'
4. Child demonstrates one addition problem with golden beads.
5. Transition to stamp game: 'Now show how the stamp game works for the same kind of problem.'
6. Child demonstrates addition on the stamp game.
7. 'Can you explain how the stamps and beads are connected?'
8. Document with photos or sketches.
materials_needed: Golden bead materials (units, tens, hundreds, thousands)

slides.heading: Math Museum
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look! We're making our very own Math Museum even bigger today! We're going to play with special math toys called golden beads and the stamp game.

slides.setup_instructions: Set up both materials on the floor mat. Have numeral cards ready.
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's get ready for our math adventure! We need our shiny golden beads, the stamp game with all its little pictures, some number cards, and a big comfy mat to play on. Ask a grown-up to help you find everything!

slides.text: 'Our Math Museum is growing! Today you will show two important materials — the golden beads and the stamp game.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Our Math Museum is getting so cool! Today, we get to show off two super fun ways to play with numbers. We'll use the golden beads and the stamp game to learn even more!

slides.text: 'Build the number 2,345 with golden beads. Tell me about each part — what does the thousand cube feel like compared to a tiny unit?'
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's build a big number with our golden beads! Can you make the number 2,345? Feel how big the thousand cube is! Then we'll talk about what each bead means.

slides.text: 'Now show me how to add two numbers with the beads. Pick any two numbers you like!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay, you built the number! Now, let's pretend we're adding some more numbers together using our golden beads. You can pick any two numbers you want to add, just like magic!

slides.text: 'Excellent! Now show the stamp game. How is it the same as the beads? How is it different?'
slides.mascot_explanation: That was amazing! Now, let's try the stamp game. See how these little stamps look like the beads? Let's see how we can use them to do the same kind of math problem.

slides.prompt: Demonstrate addition with both golden beads and the stamp game. Explain to your parent how each material works and how they connect to each other!
slides.mascot_explanation: You did so great showing me the golden beads and the stamps! Can you tell me how they are like each other, and how they are a little bit different? It's like they're math buddies!

slides.text: 'You showed how numbers work with two different materials! The beads are big and heavy — the stamps are small and quick. But they both show the same math!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child build multi-digit numbers and perform addition with both materials, explaining the connection between them?
slides.mascot_explanation: You are such a super math whiz! You showed how to make big numbers and add them with both the heavy golden beads and the quick little stamps. They both help us understand numbers, just in different ways!

parent_notes: The progression from golden beads (fully concrete — you can feel the weight of 1,000) to stamp game (semi-abstract — small tiles representing quantities) is one of Montessori's genius transitions. When your child can explain this connection, they demonstrate true mathematical understanding, not just procedural skill. The stamp game is the bridge to abstract computation. Notice how the child handles the exchange process (trading 10 units for 1 ten) — this is the concrete foundation of carrying and borrowing that will serve them through elementary mathematics. Celebrate their ability to teach — if they can teach it, they truly understand it.

title: Design Your Own Experiment — Question and Hypothesis
description: The child uses the scientific method independently for the first time, choosing their own question and forming a hypothesis. This capstone project demonstrates their understanding of how science works.
instructions:
1. 'All year we have done science experiments. Today YOU get to design your own!'
2. Review the scientific method steps on a chart: Question, Hypothesis, Experiment, Observe, Conclude.
3. Brainstorm questions: 'What have you wondered about? What do you want to test?'
4. Help the child narrow to a testable question (e.g., 'Do plants grow faster in sunlight or shade?' 'Which paper airplane design flies farthest?').
5. Write the question clearly.
6. 'What do you THINK will happen? That is your hypothesis — your best guess based on what you know.'
7. Write the hypothesis. Plan what materials are needed.
materials_needed: Brainstorming list of past experiments for inspiration

slides.heading: My Experiment
slides.mascot_explanation: Look! Today is a super special day because YOU get to be the main scientist and think up your very own experiment! We're going to learn all about asking questions, just like real scientists do.

slides.setup_instructions: Post the scientific method steps where the child can see them. Have the science journal open to a fresh page.
slides.mascot_explanation: Here are the special tools we need for our science adventure! We have a science journal to write and draw in, a pencil to help us, and a chart that shows us all the steps scientists use. Let's put the chart where we can see it!

slides.text: 'All year we have been scientists together. We observed, we tested, we learned. Now it is YOUR turn to be the lead scientist!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, you have been such a good scientist all year, helping me with all our experiments! Now, it's your turn to be the boss scientist and decide what we're going to learn.

slides.text: 'A scientist starts with a QUESTION — something they wonder about. What have YOU been wondering? What do you want to find out?'
slides.mascot_explanation: Every great experiment starts with a question! What is something you've wondered about when we play or when you see things outside? What do you really want to find out?

slides.text: 'Great question! Now we need a HYPOTHESIS — that is your best guess about what will happen. What do you THINK the answer will be?'
slides.mascot_explanation: After we ask our question, we make a guess about what we think will happen. This guess is called a hypothesis, and it's like your super smart prediction! What do you *think* will be the answer to your question?

slides.text: 'Write your question and your hypothesis in your journal. Draw a picture of what you think will happen.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's time to write down our amazing question and our smart guess, our hypothesis, in your journal. You can also draw a picture of what you think will happen in your experiment!

slides.prompt: Write your science question and hypothesis in your journal. Draw a picture of your prediction. Make a list of materials you will need for your experiment!
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's get our science journal ready! We'll write down your special question and your best guess, your hypothesis. Then, draw a picture of what you think will happen, and let's make a list of the cool things we'll need to do your experiment!

slides.text: 'You have a question, a hypothesis, and a plan! Tomorrow we will set up your experiment and find out if your hypothesis is correct!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child formulate a testable question and make a reasonable hypothesis based on prior knowledge?
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay! You have your question, you made a guess, and you even have a plan for what you need! Tomorrow, we'll get to build your experiment and see if your guess was right. You did such a great job today!

parent_notes: Designing their own experiment is the ultimate demonstration of scientific thinking. The child must draw on everything they have learned: observation skills, prediction, understanding of variables. Help them choose a question that is genuinely testable with household materials. Good capstone experiments include: comparing plant growth conditions, testing which materials are waterproof, paper airplane design, dissolving rates of different substances, magnet strength testing. The hypothesis does not need to be correct — the point is making a prediction based on reasoning. If the child's question is too broad ('Why is the sky blue?'), help them narrow it to something testable ('Does blue food coloring spread differently in hot water versus cold water?').

title: Self-Portrait — Then and Now
description: The child creates two self-portraits side by side: one drawn in the style of how they drew at the beginning of the year, and one showing their current artistic ability. This powerfully demonstrates their growth.
instructions:
1. 'Artists often look at how their art has changed over time. Let's see how YOUR art has grown!'
2. Show the child their earliest self-portrait or drawing from the year (if saved).
3. Fold a large paper in half. Label left side 'Beginning of the Year' and right side 'Now.'
4. 'On the left, try to draw yourself the way you used to draw — simple, like when you were just starting.'
5. 'On the right, draw yourself NOW, using all the skills you have learned — details, proportions, colors, backgrounds.'
6. Compare the two: 'Look at the difference! Your hands and eyes have learned so much!'
7. Add to portfolio.

slides.heading: Self-Portrait
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at this! We're going to make a special picture of you, two times! We'll draw how you used to look in your pictures and how you look right now. It's like a picture adventure to see how much you've learned!

slides.setup_instructions: Fold the paper in half and label both sides. Set up a mirror at the child's eye level. Find an early-year drawing if possible.
slides.mascot_explanation: To make our special pictures, we need a few things. We have a big piece of paper, a pencil to draw with, and fun colors like crayons or colored pencils. We also have a mirror so you can see your own happy face, and we'll look at a drawing you made a long, long time ago. Can you help a grown-up find all these things?

slides.text: 'Let's look at one of your drawings from the very beginning of the year. Do you remember making this? What do you notice about it?'
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's look at a picture you made when we first started school. Remember this one? Take a good peek at it and see what you think it looks like. What do you see in this drawing?

slides.text: 'On the left side of your paper, draw yourself the way you USED to draw — simple, like at the start of the year.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, on this side of your paper, let's draw a picture of you, just like you used to draw at the beginning of the year. Try to make it simple and fun, like you did before you learned all your new drawing tricks.

slides.text: 'Now on the right side, draw yourself the way you draw NOW. Use the mirror! Look at your eyes, your hair, your clothes. Add details and colors!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now for the other side! This is where you get to draw yourself right now. Look in the mirror and see all the cool things about you – your eyes, your hair, maybe a special shirt! Try to put all those details and colors in your drawing.

slides.text: 'Hold them up together. Look at the difference! Your art has grown so much. What do you notice?'
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's hold both your pictures up together! See how different they are? One is like the beginning, and one is like you today. Your drawing hands have learned so many new things, haven't they?

slides.prompt: Complete both self-portraits. On the left: how you used to draw. On the right: your best self-portrait using everything you have learned. Use the mirror for details!
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's time to finish your two pictures! On one side, draw yourself like you used to, and on the other side, draw yourself now with all the amazing details you can do. Use the mirror to help you make your 'now' picture super special and colorful! You can do it!

slides.text: 'What an incredible difference! Your eyes see more details now and your hands can draw what you see. That is real growth!'
slides.mastery_check: Does the 'now' portrait show significantly more detail, proportion, and artistic skill than the 'then' version?
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at that! Your two pictures show how much you've grown as an artist. You can see more things and draw them better now. It's so cool to see how much your drawing has changed, you're doing such a great job!

parent_notes: This side-by-side comparison is one of the most powerful demonstrations of growth. The contrast between a beginning-of-year self-portrait (typically a circle head with stick limbs) and an end-of-year portrait (proportional body, details like eyelashes, fingers, clothing patterns, backgrounds) is often dramatic. Some children may resist drawing 'badly' on purpose — reassure them it is fun to see the difference. If you do not have early artwork, have the child draw with their non-dominant hand on the left side to approximate the earlier skill level. Frame or photograph this — it is a keepsake that families treasure. This activity also builds metacognitive awareness: the child can SEE their own learning.

title: My Year Portfolio — Creating Page Labels and Reflections
description: The child continues building their portfolio by writing labels and short reflections for each selected piece. They practice articulating what they learned and why each piece matters to them.
instructions:
1. Retrieve the portfolio binder with selected work from Day 1.
2. 'Now each piece needs a label so people know what it is and why it is special.'
3. For each piece, help the child write: the title/name, when they made it, and one sentence about it.
4. 'What did you learn when you made this? How did it make you feel?'
5. Attach labels with tape or glue.
6. Arrange pages in chronological order: fall, winter, spring.
7. Create a cover page: 'My Year in Montessori — [Child's Name]'
8. Add a table of contents if the child is able.

slides.heading: My Year Portfolio
slides.mascot_explanation: Look! We're making a special book called a portfolio to show all the wonderful things you've done this year. It will have labels to tell everyone what each picture or project is and why it's special to you!

slides.setup_instructions: Have the portfolio binder open with all selected work. Cut index cards to size for labels.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at all these things we need to make our portfolio super special! We have your big portfolio book, some paper for making labels, a pencil to write with, and tape or glue to stick everything down. Let's ask a grown-up to help us gather all these treasures!

slides.text: 'Your portfolio is taking shape! Now each piece needs a label — just like in a museum, so visitors know what they are looking at.'
slides.mascot_explanation: This is like getting ready for a special show! We need to put little signs, called labels, on all your amazing work so everyone knows what it is. It's like telling a story about each piece, just like in a museum!

slides.text: 'For this first piece, write what it is called and when you made it. Then write one sentence: Why is this in your portfolio?'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we get to write a special note for one of your favorite things. First, we'll write what it's called and when you made it, like a date. Then, we'll write one sentence to tell us why you picked it – what makes it so special to you?

slides.text: 'Let's make your cover page! Write your name nice and big. Add a drawing of something that represents your year.'
slides.mascot_explanation: It's time to make the cover for our amazing book! We'll write your name right on the front so everyone knows it's yours. You can also draw a picture of something that you loved doing this year to make it extra pretty!

slides.text: 'Put everything in order — things from the beginning of the year first, then winter, then spring.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's put all your wonderful creations in order, like telling a story from the beginning. We'll put the things you made when it was cold outside first, then the things from when it was warm. This way, it shows all the fun we had through the whole year!

slides.prompt: Write a label for each piece in your portfolio. Include the name, when you made it, and why you chose it. Decorate your cover page!
slides.mascot_explanation: We get to do a super fun job now! We'll write a special label for each of your amazing projects, telling us what it is and why you love it. Then, we'll make your cover page look super cool. You're doing such a great job making your portfolio!

slides.text: 'Your portfolio is beautiful! It tells the story of your whole year. We can share it with family and friends — they will be so impressed!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child write descriptive labels and organize work chronologically?
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay! Look at your beautiful portfolio, you made it! It’s like a book of all your adventures and learning from this whole year. Everyone will love seeing all the amazing things you did – they’ll be so proud of you!

parent_notes: The labeling process deepens reflection — the child must think about WHY a piece matters, not just WHAT it is. This metacognitive skill (thinking about thinking, learning about learning) is a cornerstone of Montessori education. Accept whatever level of writing the child can produce for labels: a single word, a phrase, or a full sentence are all appropriate. The chronological organization teaches sequencing and helps the child see their own trajectory. This portfolio will be a cherished keepsake. Consider making color copies of favorite pages so the originals can be preserved while copies are shared. The portfolio also serves as a natural assessment tool — it shows you exactly what the child has accomplished.

title: My Book — Illustrations and Details
description: The child illustrates each page of their personal book and adds any finishing details to the text. The illustrations bring the story to life and demonstrate the connection between visual art and storytelling.
instructions:
1. 'Your words are written! Now let's add illustrations to bring your book to life.'
2. Start with the cover: 'The cover illustration should show what the whole book is about.'
3. Work through each page, drawing pictures that match the text.
4. Encourage details: background, color, expression on faces.
5. Re-read each page after illustrating: 'Does the picture match the words?'
6. Add any final text details: page numbers, 'The End' on the last page.
7. 'Tomorrow we will practice reading it out loud!'

slides.heading: My Very Own Book
slides.mascot_explanation: Look, we have a special book! It says "My Very Own Book" and it’s "Illustration Day," which means we get to draw all the pictures! It’s going to be so much fun making our story look amazing.

slides.setup_instructions: Open the booklet to the cover page. Lay out all coloring supplies.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at all these fun things we get to use to make our book super pretty! We have our special book with the words already inside, and then we have colorful crayons, bright markers, and even a pen for drawing. Let's ask a grown-up to help us get these ready so we can start making art!

slides.text: 'An author writes the words, and an illustrator draws the pictures. Today you are BOTH! Let's make your book beautiful.'
slides.mascot_explanation: You know how some people write the words in a book? Well, they are called authors! And some people draw the pictures, they are called illustrators. Today, you get to be BOTH an author and an illustrator, which is super special, and we’re going to make your book look so beautiful!

slides.text: 'Start with the cover. What picture will show people what your book is about? Draw it big and colorful!'
slides.mascot_explanation: First, let’s make the cover of our book look super exciting! Think about what your whole story is about. What picture would show everyone what’s inside? Let’s draw that big and bright right here on the front!

slides.text: 'Now each page. Read your words, then draw a picture that shows what is happening. Add lots of details — background, colors, expressions.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we’ll go page by page. For each page, we’ll read the words you wrote, and then draw a picture that matches! Let’s add lots of colors and make the people in the pictures smile or look happy, and don't forget to draw the sky and grass in the background!

slides.text: 'Add page numbers at the bottom: 1, 2, 3... And write THE END on your last page!'
slides.mascot_explanation: It’s time to make our book look even more like a real book! We need to put numbers at the bottom of each page, like 1, 2, 3, so everyone knows what order to read them in. And on the very last page, we’ll write "The End" to tell everyone our story is finished.

slides.prompt: Illustrate every page of your book! Make your pictures detailed and colorful. They should help tell the story along with your words.
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay, it’s time to draw all the pictures for our book! Let’s fill every page with colorful drawings that match the words you wrote. Make them super detailed and bright, so they help tell the story. You can do it!

slides.text: 'Your book has words AND pictures now! It looks like a real book from the library. Tomorrow we will practice reading it so you can present it to the family!'
slides.mastery_check: Are illustrations relevant to the text, detailed, and consistent throughout the book?
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at your amazing book! It has all your words and now beautiful, colorful pictures too – it looks like a real book from the library! Tomorrow, we’ll practice reading it out loud so you can show your family how wonderful your book is. You did such a great job!

parent_notes: Illustration is not just decoration — it is a form of visual literacy. Notice how the child's illustrations have evolved from early-year scribbles or disconnected shapes to images that tell a story and match the text. This is the integration of multiple skills: comprehension (understanding what to draw), fine motor (controlling the drawing tools), and artistic expression (choosing colors, adding detail). Do not rush this process. Some children may need extra time — illustration is deeply absorbing work. If the child wants to add more text after seeing their illustrations, encourage it! The interaction between words and images is how picture books work, and the child is learning this firsthand.

title: Math Portfolio — Bead Chains and Skip Counting Demonstration
description: The child demonstrates mastery of bead chains, showing skip counting, identifying squares, and explaining the patterns they discovered throughout the year.
instructions:
1. 'More Math Museum today! Let's show the bead chains.'
2. Child selects 2-3 bead chains (suggest chains of 3, 5, and 10).
3. Lay out the chain of 3: child skip counts by 3s, placing arrows at each multiple.
4. 'What number is 3 times 3? That is 3 squared! Show me the square of 3.'
5. Repeat with chain of 5: skip count by 5s, identify 5 squared (25).
6. Chain of 10: count by 10s to 100.
7. 'You know your multiplication! All from counting beads.'
8. Document for the portfolio.

slides.heading: Math Museum
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look! We're going to the Math Museum today, and we're going to play with special bead chains that help us learn about numbers. It's going to be so much fun!

slides.setup_instructions: Place bead chains and squares on the shelf for the child to retrieve. Prepare arrow labels.
slides.mascot_explanation: We need some special things for our museum today! See these colorful strings of beads? Those are our bead chains, and we also have little squares made of beads. We'll use these arrows to mark our numbers, and we'll take a picture to remember all our cool math work!

slides.text: 'Time for more Math Museum! Today: the bead chains. Which chain would you like to start with?'
slides.mascot_explanation: It's time for our Math Museum! We get to play with the bead chains now. Let's pick one of our special chains to start our counting adventure with. Which one looks most fun to you?

slides.text: 'Lay it out straight and count by threes: 3, 6, 9... Place an arrow at each number. You're skip counting!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, let's take our chain and lay it out nice and straight. Now, we're going to count by threes! We'll say "3, 6, 9" and put a little arrow on each number as we count. This is called skip counting!

slides.text: '3 times 3 is 9 — that is 3 SQUARED! See how the bead square has 9 beads? The chain folds into that square!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at this! When we count by threes, three times, we get to the number 9. See how this bead square also has 9 beads? That means our chain of three can fold up perfectly to make this square! It's like magic math!

slides.text: 'Now show me the 5 chain. Count by fives! What is 5 squared? Can you show it?'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's try our chain of five! We'll lay it out and skip count by fives this time. Can you guess what number we get when we count five fives? It's called "5 squared," and it makes a special square of beads too!

slides.prompt: Lay out bead chains, place arrows at the multiples, and demonstrate skip counting. Show how the chains connect to the bead squares!
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's get all our bead chains out and count them by threes and fives. We'll put the arrows on the numbers and see how the chains make squares. It's like we're building our very own math museum with all the cool things we've learned!

slides.text: 'Skip counting is really multiplication! You have been doing multiplication with beads all year. That is amazing!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child skip count fluently with at least two chains and explain the connection between chains and squares?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did such a wonderful job counting with the beads! You learned that skip counting is just like multiplying, and you showed me how the chains make squares. You are such a super math star!

parent_notes: Bead chains are one of Montessori's most brilliant materials because they make multiplication tangible. When a child skip counts the chain of 5 (5, 10, 15, 20, 25) and then folds the chain into the bead square (5x5=25), they FEEL multiplication and squaring. This is not rote memorization — it is deep structural understanding. Many elementary teachers are astounded when Montessori children arrive already understanding squares and skip counting. During the demonstration, let the child work at their own pace. If they stumble on a count, give them time — the beads are self-correcting. Photograph the laid-out chains with arrows for the portfolio; these make impressive documentation.

title: Cultural Tapestry — Celebrations Around the World Review
description: The child reviews all the cultural celebrations and traditions they learned about this year. They create a 'Cultural Tapestry' page showing their favorite celebrations from different countries and what they learned about respecting differences.
instructions:
1. 'This year we learned about celebrations from many countries! Let's remember them all.'
2. Look through cultural work from the year — any crafts, drawings, or notes from cultural studies.
3. Brainstorm together: Diwali, Chinese New Year, Day of the Dead, Hanukkah, Kwanzaa, Carnival, etc.
4. 'Which ones were your favorites? What did you like about them?'
5. On a large paper divided into sections, draw and label favorite celebrations.
6. Write in the center: 'People celebrate in many different ways. Every celebration is special.'
7. Discuss: 'What did all these celebrations have in common?'

slides.heading: Cultural Tapestry
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at this pretty title! It says "Cultural Tapestry" and "Celebrations Around the World." That means we get to remember all the fun parties and special days we learned about from different places!

slides.setup_instructions: Divide the large paper into 6-8 sections. Gather any cultural crafts or notes from throughout the year.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, we need some things to make our special tapestry! We need big paper for drawing, and colorful pencils or markers to make it bright. We also need to find our old crafts and papers from when we learned about these celebrations. Oh, and a globe to see where all these places are!

slides.text: 'We traveled the world through celebrations this year! Let's remember all the holidays and traditions we explored together.'
slides.mascot_explanation: This year, we went on a big adventure all around the world without even leaving our classroom! We learned about so many super fun celebrations and traditions from people in different countries. Let's think about all the exciting things we discovered!

slides.text: 'Who remembers Diwali? What about Chinese New Year? Day of the Dead? What do you remember about each one?'
slides.mascot_explanation: Remember when we learned about Diwali, the festival of lights? Or Chinese New Year with the dragon dances? And Day of the Dead, where people remember loved ones? What else do you remember about these special days?

slides.text: 'Choose your favorites and draw them — one in each section. Add the name and the country.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's pick your very favorites from all the celebrations we learned about. You get to draw a picture of each one in its own little box on your paper. Don't forget to write the name of the celebration and the country it comes from!

slides.text: 'Now think: what do ALL these celebrations have in common? They all bring people together! They all have special food, music, and traditions.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Think about all those amazing celebrations. What do you think they all have in common? Even though they look different, they all bring people together to share happy times, yummy food, and special songs.

slides.prompt: Draw your favorite celebrations in each section. Label them with the name and country. In the middle, write what celebrations have in common.
slides.mascot_explanation: It's time to make your beautiful tapestry! Draw your favorite celebrations in each box, just like we talked about, and write their names and countries. Then, in the middle, we'll write that all these special days bring people together to share happy things.

slides.text: 'Every culture has beautiful traditions. What we learned is that even though celebrations look different, they are all about the same things: family, gratitude, and joy.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child name at least 5 cultural celebrations from different countries and identify common themes across cultures?
slides.mascot_explanation: We did it! You remembered so many wonderful celebrations from all over the world. It's so cool that even though people celebrate in different ways, it's all about family, being thankful, and feeling happy together.

parent_notes: Cultural awareness is a cornerstone of Montessori's vision of peace education. By this point in the year, the child should have a genuine appreciation for diversity — not just tolerance, but celebration of differences. The key insight to guide them toward is that all cultures share universal human needs: gathering with loved ones, expressing gratitude, marking the seasons, honoring ancestors. When the child sees these commonalities, they develop the foundation for global citizenship. The Cultural Tapestry becomes a visual representation of their expanded worldview. Display it proudly — it represents a year of growing empathy and understanding.

title: Read-Aloud: The Wonderful Things You Will Be by Emily Winfield Martin
description: Reading 'The Wonderful Things You Will Be' by Emily Winfield Martin, a lyrical celebration of all the potential inside every child.
instructions:
1. Show the cover. 'This book is about all the wonderful things you might become.'
2. Read aloud — the rhyming text is like a love letter to children.
3. Pause at each spread to discuss: 'What is this child doing? Being brave? Being kind? Being curious?'
4. Personal connection: 'Which of these things are you already? Which do you want to be?'
5. Discuss: 'The book says I love everything you will be. What does that mean?'
6. Affirm the child: they are already wonderful.
materials_needed: The Wonderful Things You Will Be by Emily Winfield Martin

slides.heading: Read-Aloud
slides.subheading: The Wonderful Things You Will Be by Emily Winfield Martin
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at this! This is the special book we get to read today. It's all about the amazing and wonderful things you can be when you grow up!

items: The Wonderful Things You Will Be book
slides.setup_instructions: Have the book ready. This is a warm, affirming read.
slides.mascot_explanation: Here's the book we'll be reading! We need this book to help us imagine all the cool things you might become.

slides.text: Cover: 'This book imagines all the wonderful things you might grow up to be. Let's read it together.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's open the book! This story is going to tell us about all the super special things you might be when you grow up. Are you ready to see?

slides.text: Read with warmth and love. The rhyming text flows beautifully — let it wash over both of you.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we get to read the story! Listen to the words, they sound like a song. We're going to read it with lots of love, just for you.

slides.text: Discuss: 'Which page was your favorite? What wonderful thing do you want to be? What wonderful things are you already?'
slides.mascot_explanation: After we read, we'll talk about what we saw! What was your favorite part? What wonderful thing do you want to be, and what wonderful things are you already?

slides.prompt: Draw a picture of yourself being something wonderful. It can be something you already are or something you want to be someday!
slides.mascot_explanation: This is the fun part! We get to draw a picture of YOU being something wonderful. You can draw something you are right now, or something you want to be when you're bigger!

slides.text: 'You are already wonderful, and you're going to be even more wonderful as you grow. I can't wait to see!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child name something wonderful they already are and something they want to become?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did such a great job with our book today! Remember, you are already wonderful, and you're going to be even more amazing as you grow. I can't wait to see all the wonderful things you do!

parent_notes: This bestselling picture book is pure affirmation. It celebrates who children are and who they might become without prescribing a path. In Montessori philosophy, we follow the child — this book embodies that spirit. It's perfect for year-end reflection or any time a child needs encouragement. Emily Winfield Martin's illustrations are gentle and inclusive.

title: Sensorial Art — Creating with Color Tablets
description: The child uses their refined color sense to create an original artwork using precise color gradations. This capstone activity demonstrates mastery of color discrimination while producing a beautiful keepsake.
instructions:
1. Bring out Color Box 3 (grading tablets).
2. 'You have learned to see so many shades of color! Today you will use that skill to create art.'
3. Child grades one color family (e.g., blue) from lightest to darkest.
4. Using paint or colored pencils in matching gradations, create a gradient artwork.
5. Options: sunset scene with graded sky, ocean with graded waves, flower with graded petals.
6. 'Match each section to the closest color tablet. Your eyes can see tiny differences!'
7. Add to portfolio or frame.
materials_needed: Watercolors or colored pencils with many shades

slides.heading: Sensorial Art
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at this! We're going to make some super special art today called "Sensorial Art." It means we'll use our amazing eyes to see all the tiny, tiny differences in colors, and then we'll paint a picture with them!

slides.setup_instructions: Set up painting supplies. Have Color Box 3 accessible for reference. Protect the work surface.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at all the things we need for our art project! We have a special box with colorful squares, some paint and brushes, paper, and a cup for water. Ask your grown-up to help you find all of these so we can start our colorful adventure!

slides.text: 'Your eyes have become experts at seeing colors! You can tell the difference between light blue and medium blue and dark blue. Today, let's paint with that skill!'
slides.mascot_explanation: You know how you can see that your favorite blue shirt is a little bit different from the sky blue? Well, your eyes have gotten SO good at seeing all those little color changes. Today, we're going to use that super skill to make a beautiful painting!

slides.text: 'First, grade the blue tablets from lightest to darkest. Now we will paint a picture that goes from light to dark, just like the tablets.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's look at these colorful squares. See how they all start out very, very light and get darker and darker? We're going to do the same thing with our paint, making a picture that goes from light colors to dark colors, just like these.

slides.text: 'Paint the top of your paper the lightest shade. Add a little more paint as you go down. Can you make it get darker and darker smoothly?'
slides.mascot_explanation: We're going to start painting at the very top of our paper with the lightest color we picked. Then, as we paint down the paper, we'll make the color a little bit darker, and a little bit darker, until we reach the bottom. Can you make it look super smooth?

slides.text: 'Beautiful! Now you can add details on top — clouds, birds, waves, flowers. The gradient is your background!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Your colorful background looks amazing! Now, we can add some fun things on top, like fluffy clouds, little birds flying, or even pretty flowers. We get to decide what our picture will be, using the colorful background we just made!

slides.prompt: Create a gradient painting — start with the lightest shade at the top and smoothly blend to the darkest at the bottom. Add details to make a scene!
slides.mascot_explanation: It's time to make our masterpiece! Let's start painting at the top with the lightest color, and then gently make it darker and darker as we move down the paper. When we're done with the colors, we can add fun little details like birds or flowers to make our picture extra special!

slides.text: 'You painted a beautiful gradient! Your eyes can see differences in color that most people never notice. That is a special skill you developed this year.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child create a visible gradient with at least 4-5 distinguishable shades in sequence?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did it! Look at your amazing painting with all the beautiful colors going from light to dark. Your eyes are so good at seeing those tiny color differences, and you used that special skill to make this wonderful art! You are such a fantastic artist!

parent_notes: This activity bridges sensorial work and artistic expression — a hallmark of Montessori education. The color grading exercises the child has practiced all year were not just about matching tablets; they were training the eye to perceive subtlety. Now that refined perception becomes a creative tool. Watercolors are ideal for gradients because adding water naturally lightens the shade. If using colored pencils, pressing lighter creates paler tones. The resulting artwork is often strikingly beautiful and demonstrates a skill that many adults struggle with. This is concrete evidence that the sensorial work 'worked' — the child sees the world with greater nuance.

title: My Book — Practice Reading Aloud
description: The child rehearses reading their completed book aloud, working on expression, volume, and page-turning. They prepare for the family presentation by practicing multiple times.
instructions:
1. 'Your book is finished! Now an author has to practice reading it to an audience.'
2. Child reads through the entire book once, quietly, to themselves.
3. 'Now read it to me. Hold it so I can see the pictures while you read — just like at the library!'
4. Offer gentle feedback: 'That part was great! Can you read this page a little louder?'
5. Practice turning pages smoothly and showing illustrations.
6. 'Let's practice one more time. This time, add EXPRESSION — make your voice match the story!'
7. If time, practice an introduction: 'My name is ___ and I am the author of ___.'
materials_needed: A comfortable reading chair or special spot
Optional: microphone or pretend microphone for fun

slides.heading: My Very Own Book
slides.mascot_explanation: Look, this is your very own book! We finished making it, and now it's time for a super fun part: practicing reading it out loud. We're going to be authors today!

slides.setup_instructions: Set up a special reading area. If possible, arrange chairs for an 'audience' (stuffed animals work great for practice).
slides.mascot_explanation: To get ready, let's find your book. We also need a cozy spot to sit, like a special reading chair, and maybe even a pretend microphone if you want to feel like a star! Ask your grown-up to help you find these things.

slides.text: 'Your book is written and illustrated! Now we practice reading it out loud, just like an author at a bookstore reading event!'
slides.mascot_explanation: You did such a great job writing and drawing in your book! Now, just like a real author who shares their story, we need to practice reading it out loud so everyone can hear all your amazing words.

slides.text: 'First, read it quietly to yourself. Make sure you remember all the words.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Before we read it to someone, let's read it to ourselves first. This helps us remember all the words and makes sure we know what comes next on each page.

slides.text: 'Now read it to me! Hold the book facing me so I can see the pictures. Read slowly and clearly.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, now it's time to read it to me! Hold your book up so I can see all the pretty pictures while you read, just like we're at the library. Read nice and slow so we can hear every word.

slides.text: 'Let's practice your introduction: My name is [your name] and I wrote this book called [title]. It is about [one sentence].'
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's practice saying hello before you read. You can say, "Hi, my name is [your name] and I wrote this book called [book title]. It's all about [one little thing the book is about]."

slides.prompt: Practice reading your book aloud at least two more times. Work on reading clearly, showing the pictures, and using expression in your voice!
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's read your book two more times, just like a real author practicing! Try to read clearly, show me the pictures, and use your super-duper voice to make the story exciting. You can do it!

slides.text: 'You sound like a professional author! The family is going to love hearing your book. You should be very proud — you wrote this entire book yourself!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child read their book fluently, hold it for the audience to see illustrations, and present with expression?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, you sound like a real author reading your book! Your family is going to be so happy to hear it. You should feel so proud because you made this whole book all by yourself!

parent_notes: Reading aloud is a distinct skill from reading silently — it requires confidence, volume control, expression, and audience awareness. By practicing in a low-pressure setting first, the child builds comfort for the family presentation. Some children are natural performers; others are shy. Both are fine. Offer specific, genuine praise: 'I loved how you made your voice excited for that part!' rather than generic 'Good job.' If the child struggles to read their own phonetic spelling, gently remind them what they meant — this is not a reading test, it is a celebration. The pretend microphone adds a fun theatrical element that can help shy children feel more confident.

title: Math Portfolio — Strip Boards and Fractions Demonstration
description: The child demonstrates mastery of addition strip board, subtraction strip board, and fraction concepts. They explain how these materials work and show specific problems.
instructions:
1. 'More Math Museum! Today: strip boards and fractions.'
2. Child sets up the addition strip board and demonstrates a problem (e.g., 7+5=12).
3. 'Explain how the strips show the answer.'
4. Subtraction strip board: demonstrate a problem (e.g., 14-6=8).
5. Move to fraction insets: show halves, thirds, fourths.
6. 'Teach me: what is one half? How do you know two fourths is the same as one half?'
7. If time: demonstrate fraction equivalencies.
8. Document for portfolio.

slides.heading: Math Museum
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at this! It says "Math Museum" and we're going to learn about some super cool math tools called strip boards and fractions today! It's like we're going to have our very own special math show!

slides.setup_instructions: Have all three materials accessible. Set up enough floor space for each demonstration.
slides.mascot_explanation: Ooh, look at all the fun things we need for our museum today! We have the strip boards for adding and taking away, and these colorful circle pieces are for fractions. We also need a big mat to play on and a camera to take pictures of our amazing work! Can you help me find all these things?

slides.text: 'Today our Math Museum grows even bigger! You will demonstrate the strip boards and fractions.'
slides.mascot_explanation: This is like our special instruction card for our math show today! It says we're going to show off the strip boards and the fractions, like being a math expert for everyone to see!

slides.text: 'Set up the addition strip board. Show me how to solve 7 plus 5. Explain each step as you go!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, now we get to play with the adding strip board! Can you put the pieces out to show 7 plus 5? Let's see how the colors help us find the answer together!

slides.text: 'Now the subtraction board. Show me 14 minus 6. How do you find the answer?'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now for the taking away strip board! Can you show me how to take 6 away from 14? Let's watch how the pieces show us what's left.

slides.text: 'Last: fractions! Show me the fraction circles. What is one half? What is one third? Can you show me that two fourths equals one half?'
slides.mascot_explanation: Time for our colorful fraction circles! Can you find the piece that is one half? What about one third? And can you show me how two of the smaller pieces are the same size as one half?

slides.prompt: Demonstrate 2 addition problems, 2 subtraction problems, and show fraction equivalencies. Teach your parent how each material works!
slides.mascot_explanation: We get to be the teachers now! Let's show someone how to do two adding problems, two taking away problems, and how the fractions can be the same size even if they look different. You can teach them all about our cool math tools!

slides.text: 'You can add, subtract, AND understand fractions! You used materials that real mathematicians would be impressed by. Your Math Museum is spectacular!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child accurately demonstrate problems on strip boards and explain fraction concepts including simple equivalencies?
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay! You did it! You showed how to add, take away, and even understand fractions – you're like a math superstar! Your Math Museum is so amazing, and everyone will be so impressed with what you learned today!

parent_notes: The strip boards provide a visual, linear model of addition and subtraction that is different from the place-value model of golden beads. Together, they give the child multiple representations of the same operations — a key mathematical strength. Fractions are notoriously difficult in conventional education but Montessori children learn them concretely with the fraction insets: they can SEE that two fourths fills the same space as one half. When your child demonstrates equivalencies, they are doing work that many older children struggle with. This is the power of concrete, sensorial mathematics. Let them take their time with each demonstration — mathematical fluency shows in confident, unhurried work.

title: Design Your Own Experiment — Conducting the Test
description: The child carries out the experiment they designed, carefully following their plan, recording observations, and collecting data. They practice careful scientific observation and documentation.
instructions:
1. Review the question and hypothesis from Day 2.
2. Gather all materials needed for the experiment.
