3. 'A real scientist follows their plan carefully and writes down EVERYTHING they notice.'
4. Help the child set up the experiment.
5. Guide documentation: 'What do you see? Draw it. Write the numbers.'
6. If the experiment requires time (plant growth), set up and make initial observations.
7. Record results in the science journal with drawings and numbers.
8. 'Tomorrow or next week we will look at our results and make conclusions!'
materials_needed: Materials specific to the child's chosen experiment

slides.heading: My Experiment
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at this, friend! It says "My Experiment" and "Testing Day." That means today we get to be super scientists and do the experiment we thought about! Isn't that exciting?

slides.setup_instructions: Gather all materials from the child's plan. Set up the experiment area. Have the science journal open to the next page.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, we need lots of cool stuff for our experiment! We have our science journal where we write and draw, a pencil to write with, and some special tools to measure things. We might even need a camera to take pictures! Go ask a grown-up to help you find all these things from your experiment plan so we can start.

slides.text: 'Today is the big day! We are going to DO your experiment! Let's review: what is your question? What is your hypothesis?'
slides.mascot_explanation: Today is the most exciting part – we get to DO our experiment! Remember how we asked that big question? And what did we guess would happen? Let's talk about it one more time before we start being amazing scientists!

slides.text: 'A good scientist sets up very carefully. Let's follow your plan step by step. Gather your materials first.'
slides.mascot_explanation: A super smart scientist always sets up their experiment just right, following their special plan. First, let's make sure we have all the things we need that we just saw. Then, we'll set up our experiment area so it's ready for all the fun!

slides.text: 'Now do the experiment! And watch closely — write down and draw EVERYTHING you notice. Every detail matters!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's time to do the experiment! Follow your plan very carefully, and watch everything super closely. We need to write down and draw everything we see, even the little things, because real scientists notice everything!

slides.text: 'Record your results. Use numbers if you can measure. Draw what you see. Be very precise!'
slides.mascot_explanation: It's time to write down what happened! If you can measure something, let's use our numbers. Let's also draw a picture of what we see. Being a good scientist means writing down all the important details!

slides.prompt: Conduct your experiment following your plan. Record everything in your science journal — draw what you see, measure, count, and write observations!
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay, you're doing it! Follow your plan step by step and do the experiment. Remember to draw what you see in your journal, use your measuring tools, count things, and write down all the cool stuff you notice. You've got this!

slides.text: 'You did it! You conducted a real scientific experiment! Now we have data. Soon we will look at the results and see if your hypothesis was right.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child follow their experimental plan, make careful observations, and record data in their journal?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did it! You are a real scientist who did a whole experiment! We have all our notes and drawings now, which is called data. Soon we will look at it all and see if your guess was right. You were so careful and did such a great job!

parent_notes: The ability to design and carry out an experiment independently is a significant milestone. Your role is to facilitate, not direct. Help with safety and logistics, but let the child drive the process. If the experiment does not go as planned, that is EXCELLENT — real science is full of unexpected results! Help the child document what actually happened, not what they expected to happen. If they are testing something that takes time (plant growth over days), help them set up a schedule for ongoing observations. For immediate experiments (paper airplane distance, dissolving rates), they can collect all data today. The emphasis is on careful observation and honest recording, not on getting the 'right' answer.

title: Year-End Concert — Practicing Favorite Songs
description: The child selects their favorite songs from the entire year and practices them for a mini family concert. This celebrates their musical growth and provides performance experience.
instructions:
1. 'Let's have a music review! What were your favorite songs from this year?'
2. Brainstorm together — seasonal songs, folk songs from cultural studies, movement songs, lullabies.
3. Child selects 4-5 favorites.
4. Practice each song together, reviewing words and melodies.
5. Decide on an order (the 'set list').
6. Practice performing: standing tall, looking at the audience, starting together.
7. 'We will have our concert for the family soon! You sound wonderful.'
materials_needed: Song lyrics sheets from throughout the year

slides.heading: Year-End Concert
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at this! We're going to have a special concert to show off all the super fun songs we learned this year. It's like a show just for our family!

slides.setup_instructions: Gather all song sheets from the year. Set up instruments. Create a small performance area.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at all our music things! We have the words to our songs so we don't forget them, and we have cool instruments like shakers and drums to make our music even more exciting. We can even pretend this is a real microphone for singing loud and proud!

slides.text: 'We have sung so many songs this year! Let's pick your absolute favorites for a special concert.'
slides.mascot_explanation: We have sung so many songs together, haven't we? Now it's time to pick your very, very favorites to sing in our special concert.

slides.text: 'Which songs do you want to perform? Think about fall songs, winter songs, songs from our cultural studies, movement songs...'
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's think about all the music we've made! Do you remember the songs we sang when it was cold outside, or the ones where we got to dance around? Which ones made you feel the happiest?

slides.text: 'Great choices! Let's practice each one. Stand up tall, take a deep breath, and sing with your best voice!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Those are such wonderful songs you picked! Now, let's stand up super straight, take a big breath, and sing them with all your might, just like a star!

slides.text: 'Now let's decide the order. Which song should be first? Which should be the grand finale?'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we need to pick which song comes first, like the opening act, and which one will be the very last, the big finish! It's like planning a story with our songs.

slides.prompt: Practice your concert set list! Sing each song all the way through. Add instruments if you like. Practice bowing at the end!
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay, let's sing our whole concert now! Sing each song from the beginning to the end, and if you want, you can play your instruments too. And don't forget to give a big bow at the end!

slides.text: 'Your concert is going to be amazing! The family will love it. You have learned so many beautiful songs this year.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child sing 4-5 songs from memory with reasonable melody and rhythm?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did such a fantastic job practicing! Your family is going to love hearing you sing all your favorite songs. You've become such a wonderful singer this year, and I'm so proud of you!

parent_notes: Music is deeply connected to memory and emotion — singing these songs will bring back memories of the experiences associated with them. The autumn leaf song might remind the child of nature walks; the Japanese folk song might recall their Asia study. This musical review is also a review of the entire year's experiences. Let the child choose freely — their selections reveal what resonated most deeply. Some children may want to play instruments while singing; others prefer voice alone. Performance anxiety is normal; keep rehearsal relaxed and fun. The goal is joyful expression, not perfection. Consider recording the concert for the family — it will be a treasured memory.

title: My Year Portfolio — Final Assembly and Presentation Preparation
description: The child completes their portfolio by adding a dedication page, a 'What I Learned' summary, and prepares to present it. The finished portfolio represents a year of growth and accomplishment.
instructions:
1. 'Today we finish your portfolio! It needs a few more special pages.'
2. Dedication page: 'Who do you want to dedicate your portfolio to? Who helped you learn this year?'
3. 'What I Learned' page: child dictates or writes 5-10 things they learned.
4. Final page: 'What I Want to Learn Next' — looking ahead to elementary.
5. Assemble all pages in order. Add a back cover.
6. Practice presenting: 'Walk us through your portfolio. Tell us about each piece.'
7. 'You will show this to the whole family!'
materials_needed: Extra paper for dedication and summary pages

slides.heading: My Year Portfolio
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at this! This is the cover of your special book that shows all the amazing things you did this whole year. We're going to make it super special today!

slides.setup_instructions: Have the portfolio binder ready with all work assembled. Prepare blank pages for dedication and summary.
slides.mascot_explanation: Here are the things we need to finish our book, like magic tools! We have your special book, some nice new paper, a pencil for writing, and lots of fun things to make it pretty. Let's ask a grown-up to help us find them all!

slides.text: 'Your portfolio is almost done! Let's add some special pages that make it complete.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay, we're almost done with your special book! We just need to add a few more pages to make it perfect, like adding the cherry on top of a yummy cake!

slides.text: 'A dedication page is where you say thank you to someone special. Who helped you learn this year? Let's write it: This portfolio is dedicated to...'
slides.mascot_explanation: This page is like sending a special hug in your book. We get to write who helped you learn all year, like your family or teachers. Let's think about who made you smile and learn!

slides.text: 'Now a page about what you learned! Tell me your favorite things you learned this year — as many as you can think of!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we get to make a page all about YOU and what you learned! What was your favorite thing you learned this year? Tell me all about it, and we can write it down!

slides.text: 'Last page: What do you want to learn NEXT YEAR? What are you excited about? Write or draw your ideas!'
slides.mascot_explanation: For this last page, we get to imagine what fun things you'll learn next! What do you want to be when you grow up, or what do you want to do? Let's draw or write your big ideas!

slides.prompt: Write your dedication, your 'What I Learned' list, and your 'What I Want to Learn Next' page. Decorate them beautifully!
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's time to put all our special pages together and make them look super beautiful! We'll write our thank yous, our favorite lessons, and our future dreams, and then we can decorate them with colors and stickers!

slides.text: 'Your portfolio is complete! It tells the story of YOUR year — all the hard work, all the learning, all the growth. This is something to be truly proud of.'
slides.mastery_check: Is the portfolio complete with cover, chronological work samples, labels, dedication, and summary pages?
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at your amazing book! You finished it! It shows how much you learned and grew this year, and that's something to be super proud of, like a superhero! You did such a wonderful job!

parent_notes: The finished portfolio is more than a collection of work — it is a narrative of the child's year. The dedication page teaches gratitude. The 'What I Learned' page builds metacognitive awareness. The 'What I Want to Learn Next' page creates excitement about continuing education. During the presentation practice, be a warm, attentive audience. Ask genuine questions about specific pieces. This portfolio will be one of the most meaningful artifacts of your child's early education. Consider making a copy for grandparents. In Montessori schools, the portfolio often serves as a key assessment tool — it shows growth across all domains in a way that tests never could.

title: My Book — Author Reading and Celebration
description: The child presents their completed personal book to family members in a formal 'author reading.' They introduce themselves as the author, read the book aloud, show illustrations, and answer questions.
instructions:
1. Set up a special reading area with a chair for the author and chairs for the audience.
2. Invite family members to the 'Book Launch Event.'
3. Child introduces themselves: 'My name is ___ and I am the author and illustrator of [title].'
4. Child reads the book aloud, showing illustrations to the audience.
5. Audience asks questions: 'What was your favorite part to write? What gave you the idea?'
6. Audience applauds! Author signs copies (if you made photocopies).
7. Celebrate with a special snack.

slides.heading: Author Reading
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at this! It says "Author Reading" and "My Book Launch!" That means today is a super special day because you get to be a real author and share your amazing book with everyone!

slides.setup_instructions: Set up a formal reading area. Arrange audience chairs facing the author's chair. Consider a small podium or music stand for the book.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, we need some things to make our book launch special! We need your finished book, a comfy chair for you to sit in like a star author, and some chairs for your family to sit and listen. Oh, and a yummy snack to celebrate when we're all done!

slides.text: 'Today is your BOOK LAUNCH! Real authors have these when they finish a book. Your family is here to hear you read!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Today is your big day! It's called a "Book Launch," and it's like a party for your book. Your family is going to be your special audience, and they can't wait to hear you read!

slides.text: 'Stand up tall and introduce yourself: My name is [name] and I wrote this book called [title]. It is about [one sentence].'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's time to introduce yourself like a famous author! Stand up nice and tall and say, "My name is [your name], and I wrote this book called [your book's title]. It's all about..." and tell them one thing your book is about.

slides.text: 'Now read your book! Hold it up so everyone can see the pictures. Read slowly and clearly.'
slides.mascot_explanation: It's time to read your wonderful book! Hold it up high so everyone can see your beautiful pictures. Remember to read nice and slow and say all the words clearly so your audience can hear every bit!

slides.text: 'After reading, your audience might have questions. Answer them like a real author! You know this book best because YOU wrote it.'
slides.mascot_explanation: After you read, your audience might want to ask you some questions, just like in a real author event! You can answer them because you know everything about your book since you made it all by yourself.

slides.prompt: Present your book to the family audience! Read with expression, show your illustrations, and answer questions about your writing process.
slides.mascot_explanation: This is the best part! You get to show everyone how amazing you are. Read your book with lots of feeling, show off your awesome drawings, and tell them about your book. You can do it!

slides.text: 'You are a published author! You wrote, illustrated, and presented your very own book. That is an incredible accomplishment. Let's celebrate!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child read their book aloud confidently, engage with the audience, and articulate their creative process?
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay! You did it! You are a real author now because you wrote and shared your book. That's super, super amazing, and you should be so proud of yourself! Let's have our special celebration snack!

parent_notes: The author reading is the culmination of the entire language curriculum. In one event, the child demonstrates: handwriting, spelling, grammar, sentence structure, storytelling, illustration, public speaking, and audience engagement. Make this feel special — set up chairs, dim lights if you want atmosphere, and be an enthusiastic audience. Ask genuine questions: 'How did you decide to include that part?' Real publishers have book launch events, so this is authentic. If possible, make color photocopies so the child can 'sign' copies for family members. Take photos. This is a milestone that deserves celebration. The confidence gained from presenting their own work to an appreciative audience has lasting impact on the child's relationship with writing and public speaking.

title: Math Museum — Grand Opening and Free Choice
description: The child presents their complete Math Museum to family, demonstrating favorite materials and explaining mathematical concepts. Then they enjoy free choice with any math material as a celebration.
instructions:
1. 'Welcome to the Grand Opening of [child's name]'s Math Museum!'
2. Child gives a tour of all the materials they demonstrated this week.
3. For each material, child gives a brief explanation: 'These are number rods. They show quantities from 1 to 10.'
4. Demonstrate one problem or concept with each material.
5. Family asks questions; child answers.
6. After the tour: 'Now it is free choice! You may work with ANY math material you want.'
7. Child selects their favorite and works independently while family observes.
8. Celebrate and photograph.
materials_needed: All math materials from the week: number rods, spindle box, golden beads, stamp game, bead chains, strip boards, fraction insets

slides.heading: Math Museum
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at this! It says "Math Museum" and "Grand Opening!" That means today we get to show everyone all the super cool math things we learned this week, like it's a real museum!

items: All math materials demonstrated this week
slides.setup_instructions: Arrange all math materials in display stations around the room, like a museum exhibit. Add small labels if desired.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, we need lots of fun things for our museum! We need all the math toys we played with, like the colorful blocks and numbers, and a soft rug to stand on, and a camera to take pictures! Ask your grown-up to help you find all the math treasures we used this week!

slides.text: 'Welcome, everyone, to the Grand Opening of the Math Museum! Our curator will now give you a tour!'
slides.mascot_explanation: It's time to be the museum guide! We're going to say "Welcome!" to our family, and then we get to show them all the amazing math things we've been working on. You're the boss of the museum tour!

slides.text: 'Start at the beginning — show the number rods, then the spindle box. Explain what each one teaches.'
slides.mascot_explanation: First, we'll show them the long skinny sticks called number rods, and then the little box with the pegs. We'll tell them how these help us learn about counting and how many things we have. You know all about them!

slides.text: 'Now the golden beads and stamp game — show a big addition problem! Then the bead chains — demonstrate skip counting!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Next, we'll show the shiny gold beads and the little number squares. We'll show them how we can put big numbers together to add them up, and then we'll use the pretty bead strings to count by twos or threes! It's like magic math!

slides.text: 'Finish with the strip boards and fractions. You have shown SO much math! Now choose your favorite material and enjoy it.'
slides.mascot_explanation: We're almost done with the tour! We'll show them the colorful strips and how they help us learn about parts of things, like pieces of a pizza. You did so much great math this week, and now you get to pick your very favorite thing to play with again!

slides.prompt: After the museum tour, choose your favorite math material and work with it freely. Show your family what you love most about math!
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay, free choice! This is your favorite part. Pick any of the math toys you love the most and play with it however you want, just for fun! Show your family how much you love math and how good you are at it!

slides.text: 'What an incredible Math Museum! You know so much about numbers, operations, and fractions. You should be so proud of your mathematical mind!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child give a coherent tour explaining multiple materials and demonstrate independent mastery of their favorite?
slides.mascot_explanation: You were an amazing museum guide and you know SO much math! You showed everyone how to count, add, and even do tricky fractions. Give yourself a big hug, you did such a wonderful job showing off your smart brain!

parent_notes: The Math Museum Grand Opening is a celebration of the entire year's mathematical journey. Having the child present as 'curator' reinforces learning through teaching and builds public speaking confidence. The free choice at the end honors the Montessori principle of following the child — watch what they choose when given freedom. Their selection reveals their mathematical passion. Some children gravitate to the sensorial beauty of bead chains; others love the challenge of stamp game operations; still others are fascinated by fractions. This preference can guide next year's emphasis. Document this extensively — the Math Museum showcases a level of mathematical understanding that astonishes most observers of young children.

title: Time Capsule — Messages to My Future Self
description: The child creates a time capsule with messages, drawings, and small items that capture who they are right now. They will open it at the end of next year to see how they have grown.
instructions:
1. 'Let's make a TIME CAPSULE! It is a collection of things that show who you are RIGHT NOW.'
2. Items to include: a current self-portrait, a handwriting sample, favorite things list, a letter to future self.
3. Help the child write a letter: 'Dear Future Me, Right now I am ___ years old. My favorite things are ___. I am learning ___. Next year I hope to ___.'
4. Add small items: a nature treasure, a photo, their height measurement.
5. Seal in a box or large envelope. Write 'DO NOT OPEN UNTIL [date next year].'
6. Put in a special place for safekeeping.

slides.heading: Time Capsule
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at this fun idea! We're going to make a special box called a time capsule to keep things that show who you are right now, like a treasure chest for yourself!

slides.setup_instructions: Have the box ready. Prepare paper for the letter and drawing. Gather small items the child might want to include.
slides.mascot_explanation: To make our time capsule, we need a box or a big envelope to put our treasures in. We'll also need paper and crayons to draw and write, and maybe some other little things that are special to you! Ask a grown-up to help you find these things.

slides.text: 'A time capsule is a special container that holds things from right NOW. We will seal it up and open it next year to see how much you have changed!'
slides.mascot_explanation: A time capsule is like a secret box for your memories! We're going to fill it with things that show how awesome you are today, then close it up tight. We'll open it again next year to see how much you've grown, like magic!

slides.text: 'First, draw a picture of yourself right now. What do you look like today? What are you wearing?'
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's make a picture of you! Can you draw what you look like right now? Think about your hair, your eyes, and maybe even what fun clothes you're wearing today!

slides.text: 'Now write a letter to your future self: Dear Future Me, I am [age] years old. My favorite color is ___. My best friend is ___. I just finished kindergarten!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we get to write a letter to yourself for next year! You can tell your future self how old you are, what your favorite things are, and maybe even who your best friend is.

slides.text: 'What else should we put in? A photo? A leaf from the garden? Your height? Think of things that show who you are today.'
slides.mascot_explanation: What else can we put inside to show who you are? Maybe a pretty leaf you found, a picture of you, or even how tall you are! We want to pick things that feel like YOU right now.

slides.prompt: Create your time capsule contents: self-portrait, letter to future self, favorite things list, and any small items that represent who you are right now.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, you're doing so great making all the special things for your time capsule! You drew a wonderful picture, wrote a super letter, and picked out neat treasures to go inside.

slides.text: 'Your time capsule is sealed! When you open it next year, you will be amazed at how much you have grown and changed. It will be like getting a letter from the past!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child articulate who they are now and express anticipation about future growth?
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay, our time capsule is all ready to be sealed! When you open it next year, you'll get to see all the cool things you did and how much you've changed. It's like a surprise from your past self!

parent_notes: The time capsule bridges the present and future in a tangible way. It teaches the child that growth is ongoing — they will be different next year, just as they are different now from the beginning of this year. Include practical measurements (height, hand tracing, shoe size) alongside emotional content (favorite things, hopes, fears). The letter to future self is particularly powerful because it captures the child's voice at this exact moment. Store the capsule somewhere safe but accessible. When opened next year, the contrast will be remarkable and deeply meaningful for both child and parent. This activity connects to the Montessori concept of the child's ongoing construction of self.

title: Read-Aloud: We're All Wonders by R.J. Palacio
description: Reading 'We're All Wonders' by R.J. Palacio, a picture book companion to Wonder that teaches children about seeing others' inner beauty and being kind.
instructions:
1. Show the cover. 'This is Auggie. He looks a little different from other kids.'
2. Read aloud with tenderness — the simple text carries deep meaning.
3. Discuss: 'Why do some people stare at Auggie?'
4. Talk about seeing with your heart, not just your eyes.
5. Discuss: 'What makes someone a wonder? Are we ALL wonders?'
6. Connect to kindness: 'How can we help people feel like the wonders they are?'
materials_needed: We're All Wonders by R.J. Palacio

slides.heading: Read-Aloud
slides.subheading: We're All Wonders by R.J. Palacio
slides.mascot_explanation: Look! We're going to read a special book together called "We're All Wonders." It's a story about a boy named Auggie, and it's going to teach us something very important about being kind.

slides.setup_instructions: Have the book ready for a gentle, important conversation.
slides.mascot_explanation: For our special story, we just need this book right here! We'll need to hold it gently because it has a really good message inside for us to talk about.

slides.text: Cover: 'This is Auggie. He was born looking different. But he does all the same things other kids do.'
slides.mascot_explanation: See this picture? This is Auggie! He looks a little different from other kids, but he likes to do the same fun things that you do.

slides.text: Read gently. The illustrations by Raul Colon are warm and expressive. Give time for the message to settle.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, we're going to read the story very gently. The pictures are so pretty and warm, and the words have a big meaning, so we'll let them sink in.

slides.text: Discuss: 'Why did some kids look away? What does it mean to see with your heart? Why are we ALL wonders?'
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's think about the story. Why do you think some people looked away from Auggie? What does it mean to see with your heart, and are we all special wonders?

slides.prompt: Write or draw one thing that makes YOU a wonder. Then write one thing that makes someone you love a wonder.
slides.mascot_explanation: It's time to be a wonder yourself! Can you draw a picture or tell me one thing that makes *you* super special? Then, let's think of one thing that makes someone you love a wonder, too!

slides.text: 'Everyone is a wonder. When we look with our hearts, we can see the wonder in everybody.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child explain what it means to be a wonder and how to see with your heart?
slides.mascot_explanation: Remember, everyone is a wonder, just like you! When we use our hearts to see people, we can find the amazing wonder in everyone we meet. You did such a great job thinking about this!

parent_notes: This picture book adaptation of Wonder is age-appropriate for young children and teaches a profound lesson about empathy, acceptance, and inner beauty. It connects to Montessori's emphasis on peace education and grace and courtesy. The message that everyone deserves kindness is simple but powerful.
